pr_contents: This PR attempts to allow mavros to accept
messages from the flight controller or GCS.  This is useful because it can allow a ground station operator to pass the position target to ROS (so that it can do the path planning) without using rviz.

Below is an image of a test using Mission Planner attached to an ArduPilot Rover with ROS running on a tx2.  I was able to select ROS using MP's upper-left vehicle selector and the right-mouse-button-click and select, "Fly To Here".  When mavros consumes the message it converts the latitude, longitude, altitude into ENU and publishes it to /mavros/setpoint_position/cmd_pos topic
Mavros's topic can be remapped to
) so that it can accept the target.
While testing I found two issues which I'm hoping the reviewers (
?) can give me a hand in resolving:
Anyway, all feedback is welcome, thanks!
I think this PR is working now and I've done a
including a couple of videos (
) showing how ROS's path planner can be used as an external navigation source for object avoidance.
, any chance this can be merged?
I'm happy to make changes but I probably need some more specific feedback on what needs changing.
I understand
's comments that we need to be careful of mixing up commands received from a GCS and those received from a vehicle but with
, the position target is now coming from the vehicle.
At the risk of overblowing this minor change, I think it a nice enhancement that allows the flight code to remain in control and only use ROS as a navigation tool when it wants to.

just because something is working for a particular case doesn't mean that we are doing things thr correct way. There is an API and an implementation logic that should always be respected, unless there's nothing we can do besides messing with the API logic.
As you can read on my review, I didn't just referenced the mixing of GCS and FCU messages. I also said that
prefix messages are sent to the flight controller,
coming from it. You can use the counter-part message to get the data from the FCU. Using the

messages here is, as I said, breaking the API and the implementation logic of this package. Doesn't make sense to have a group of messages which usage is respecting the API implementation and then have a case where this is change with no aparent reason.
I'm happy to make changes but I probably need some more specific feedback on what needs changing.
As a reviewer, I gave a specific feedback on what needs to be changed :) I am happy to help you make this implementation correct (not make it work, cause it seems to be).
I understand

's comments that we need to be careful of mixing up commands received from a GCS and those received from a vehicle but with these enhancements to ArduPilot Rover, the position target is now coming from the vehicle.
I wonder if this is correct from the Mavlink API standpoint. Again,
prefixes is something you send from a offboard controller to the FCU, not the other way around.

, thanks again for the feedback.  So the objection is with the SET_TARGET_POSITION_GLOBAL_INT messages coming from the FCU?  I think we haven't had SET_ messages come from the FCU only because we haven't previously tried to make the flight controller the "master".  I.e. the flight controller has always been the "leaf".. it's been pushed around by upper level controllers within ROS.  I don't really see why there would be a restriction on a flight controller providing a position target to ROS's navigation controller... and if we accept that it is OK for a flight controller to provide a position target to ROS, I don't see how it would get it there unless it used the SET_TARGET_POSITION_GLOBAL_INT message (or the very similar SET_TARGET_POSITION_LOCAL_NED)..
.. by the way, I'm very happy to having a voice chat somewhere if that would help speed things along.. we could use
but skype or hangouts or whatever also works for me.

this is not a matter of what has been tried or not. Is what the API is set to do and changing that paradigm first needs a discussion on the Mavlink API. We can't just assume we can use a message in a certain way just becaude it works. Then we would be using all the messages the way we wanted.
You can actually read on the message description the following:
"Used by an external controller to command the vehicle (manual controller or other system)."
If one wants to update the Mavlink protocol API, then one should suggest that same change first, and not apply the message in a certain way that contradicts the API.
Besides really confusing message usage (with it's description),
I'd like to see that as a separate plugin. That should give more clear separation of commanding setpoints
and "guidance receiver" (better to find new name, that will not include
, as they treated as "fly there" command).
Also perhaps that should be in extras, as it have very specific usage.
pr_quotes: I'm happy to make changes but I probably need some more specific feedback on what needs changing.
I understand

's comments that we need to be careful of mixing up commands received from a GCS and those received from a vehicle but with these enhancements to ArduPilot Rover, the position target is now coming from the vehicle.
"Used by an external controller to command the vehicle (manual controller or other system)."
pr_details_more: something seems incorrect with the conversion from lat/lon to ENU.  The north-south values seem to be reversed.  If I click to the north of the vehicle (in mission planner) the target (as viewed in rviz) appears to the south of the vehicle (or more accurately to the right of the vehicle which is facing east).  The East-West calculations seem ok.
I had to force the z-axis output to zero (see comment, "force z-axis to zero") because I'm using a rover and ROS's navigation didn't seem happy unless the target has position of zero.

I wanted to get the IP of the ground control station that mavros/mavconn connects to, so I made this change. I'm not sure if this is something you want in the upstream mavros, but I'm making this PR to find out.
It runs a 1 Hz timer in the main mavros loop that checks the ip stored in the MAVConnUDP instance (through a new public const method), and publishes it on a latched topic
. It only does this once.
This implementation works, but it feels like it could be integrated in a nicer way. All suggestions appreciated.

pr_title: Improving behavior of the planner to follow peak points of the global plan strictly.
pr_contents: Hello Sir,

I have made certain changes to the existing teb_local_planner. It was seen that the teb_local_planner did not follow the peak points of the global plan strictly. It is required because if the teb_local_planner follows the peak points of the global plan strictly, the local planner works more efficiently in terms of time as well as the robot does not get stuck. I have experienced that with the changes made in the code, the robot takes less time than the normal time elapsed to follow the same goal in the existing teb_local_planner.Also, the teb_local_planner does not get stuck in infinite loops of finding an alternative path. In the peakViaPoints( ), I have created a method so that the planner publishes a viaPoint at the peak of the goal plan taken into consideration by the teb_local_planner. Please look forward to the changes I have made.
-- Mudit Jindal
Thank you very much for the proposed changes.
I like the idea to add just significant viapoints instead of using the current naive uniform grid.
However, I have some comments that I would like you to address or discuss before merging.

A general discussion: is it sufficient for most scenarios to find just one peak point or should we try to find all local maxima and local mimima of the curvature of the transformed plan to have all peak points?
Hello,

Local planner should try to find all local maxima and local mimima of the curvature of the transformed plan to have all peak points. All these peak points will act as sub-goals for the local planner which will result in better traceability of the global plan.
Rgds
Nitin
Hello Sir,
I have been a bit busy due to my college exams. Currently trying to move peak-point computation into updateViaPointsContainer. I will update the code in the following week.
Hello,

I have made changes according to ROS C++ styleguide. But cannot find an alternative to change parameters max_number_classes or  enable_multithreading. This is required because max_number_classes while using
, max_number_classes  should be equal to 1. This saves computation cost in terms of time taken to reach the goal.
Moving the method
into
is not required because via points follow the strict order when
is
. Even while using uniform via points with peakViaPoint( ) and
is
, a strict order is followed.

pr_title: Added moveit config for Mico arm 6 dof 2 fingers
pr_contents: I created a moveit configuration package for the Mico arm with 6 dofs and 2 fingers. It worked in my testing of the arm.
HI

Sorry for the huge delay in answering you. Thanks for your work. Can you confirm that you are working on Ubuntu 14.04/Ros Indigo? I fear that some changes that you have done make the package not compatible anymore with Indigo. I like the work on the moveit package for MICO 6dof with 2 fingers though.
Also, I checked you changes in kinova_description/urdf/kinova_finger_set.xacro. Why did you need those changes? What is the added value?
I see also some changes in kinova_moveit/kinova_arm_moveit_demo/src/pick_place.cpp and on kinova_moveit/kinova_arm_moveit_demo/src/motion_plan.cpp I am not sure of (you comment out some parts)
You also made some changes in the action servers. How do they affect the default behaviour?
Thank you
Martine
Hi

When I had originally initiated this pull request I had only added the configuration files for a 6 dof Mico arm. Because the project I was working on moved well past that I ended up adding a significant number of changes to the master branch of the repo and so many of those commits have broken the repo to a point that I would not advise merging this branch into the main kinova-ros repo. I would really appreciate some advice/guidance as to which changes you'd like to see merged and I can recreate them in separate branches and submit pull requests if you'd like.
My main contributions have been:
Let me know your thoughts and I am happy to redo this pull request to merge them in.
Best Regards,
David Watkins
Hi
Thanks for answering. I was especially interested by the m1n6s200 moveit package you have created.
We also have the plan to transition towards 16.04, but right now, it is not done yet.

If I understand correctly, your modified pick place demo does not use open loop velocity control. That's great, because the open loop control does lead to some inaccuracies. We have implemented some kind of PID/closed loop control in the branch dev/improved_precision_moveit with the help of
The main changes are in
(we are actually calling to a new file
in the moveit (robot)_demo.launch files instead).
Nonetheless, our official branch is still master since those changes have not been validated extensively.
I let you look at that if this is of any interest.
Cheers
Martine
I'll have to take a look at this. It looks promising. I'd love to see a cleaner implementation then mine for the trajectory controller.
A controller for the hand would be pretty great too. How do you get feedback from the gripper? I wasn't aware there were encoders in the hand?
pr_details_more: When using the Mico hand in MoveIt!, the configuration for the fingers was incorrect and would not correctly display the entire end effector when a grasp plan was unsuccessful and would instead only display the fingers. I modified
to correctly display the entire end effector.

I only used ROS Kinetic 16.04. Since 14.04 is going to go out of LTS in less than a year I think it is smarter to work either exclusively in 18.04 or 16.04, melodic or kinetic, moving forward. Unsure if you have started officially supporting this since I have not been using Indigo for quite some time now.

I had to modify the pick place demo because the code you guys wrote for the joint action server assumed three fingers and only performed open loop velocity control. I had to modify the API significantly and did not have time to fix the pick and place demo. If you wanted me to merge these changes I would fix the pick place demo. The ideal controller would be a PID controller but I haven't had time to write one myself. Open loop velocity control resulted in erroneous trajectories and very frequently the hand would be in an unexpected location.

This looks great! What did you do differently to make the solver have a higher solve rate? Also can you include the output of the IKFast solver rate test?
Here are two instructions that show you how to run these tests:
The key thing we should document is the outcome of this line:
Which is generated from this command:
pwd
pwd
key part being the --iktests flag

In my opinion, the problem is that the current robot description (URDF, meshes, xacro) of Kinova manipulators is not suited for calculating a closed-form solution with IKFast. First, because the solver I've generated took about one hour to compute, while typical IKFast solvers are obtained in at most 10 minutes (see
). Second, the solution provided with these solvers (including Jaco 7, as far as I know, and tested) carries a "big" approximation error, in the order of 10^-3.

I also think the mico has a fundamentally challenging IK problem and tbh the manipulability is not great. I think this comes from the non spherical wrist, while neat its not a great idea from a kinematic perspective. Did you get a chance to run the IKFast test? If this has a high solve rate (I believe the current one in kinova master has a solve rate of 50-60%) It should definitely go in.

pr_contents: This PR adds generic features for Gazebo simulation as well as for integrating Kinova arms into more complex robotic systems. In particular, it includes:
EdgeAcceleration: limitation of steering rate
EdgeKinematics: limitation steering angle
EdgeInflatedObstacle: squared decay for inflation radius, high cost for min obstacle distance
EdgeVelocity: penalty for omega, if leading to a smaller turning radius than possible

data to
messages as it implies that the robot has sensors / capabilities that it really does not. This makes me hesitant to merge something like this.

that this could easily cause confusion if published directly.

pr_title: Add Kuka cybertech KR16 R1610 support
pr_contents: This adds support for the Kuka cybertech KR16 R1610 model. It does not have that much in common with the Kuka KR16-2 already supported. Therefore I added completely separate packages.

In the technical specification [1] it is referred to as "kr16 r1610" ie omitting the "cybertech" part. I added it to the package name anyway as it helps in distinguishing the product lines. We will test this one on real hardware starting next week so it should not be merged yet. I would however be grateful about naming advice and therefore open the PR already.
Just a small update: this package has been used and tested extensible now.
The ikfast plugin was created on kinetic and seems to create problems here on indigo (C++98vsC++11?)
In this pull request there are modifications of KRL files needed for RSI v4. Also it includes support for 8 digital outputs. Testing performed on KRC C4 Compact with KR10.

pr_title: adding compatibility to RSI 4.x by providing a seperate ros_rsi.rsix
pr_contents: Tested on KSS 8.5
This commit adds support for the original KR3 robot arm, which is also mechanically the same as Thermo-CRS F3 robot arm.

The measurements are based on the drawings available from KUKA. For 3D models, I started with the  STEP files available from KUKA, converted them to STL with FreeCAD and then simplified in Blender for the collision models. Link 4 required some manual editing to avoid false collisions with link 2.

Note that this is my first foray into ROS, so I might have made some silly newbie mistake somewhere. But this model appears to work correctly for me in simulation, though I don't have the interface to the real robot up yet.

pr_title: Fix stuck in local minimum / excess loops in path
pr_contents: These two commits provide a practical solution to the problem of the
planner getting stuck in a sub-optimal local minimum. Commonly, these
local minima cause the robot to perform excess loops on its way to the
goal. The solution solves the problem probabilistically by allowing the
multi-homotopy class planner to maintain a second candidate path in the
same homotopy class as the current "best" path. This allows path
exploration to "discover" new paths in a different, potentially better
local minimum, typically leading to the most optimal such alternative
being found.
This solves the following open issues:
It may also address this issue, but I am uncertain what the author means
by "teb cannot converge the path to a good solution.":
The second commit in this series not only improves the chances of
getting out of a local minimum but also improves the chances of finding
a better path around obstacles because it does not keep all the
candidate slots full with only the first few homotopy classes discovered
in exploration.

pr_contents: In testing, I found that setting the new parameter
control_look_ahead_poses to 3 improved path following
accuracy very much. However, in cases where need to arrive
at a very precise goal (as by setting xy_goal_tolerance to 0.01),
it could cause the robot to overshoot the goal and then oscillate
back and forth over the goal indefinitely.
This new parameter fixes that by preventing
control_look_ahead_poses from selecting one of the last few
poses of the path.
Since this new dynamic parameter affects the behavior of an
existing parameter, it makes sense to make the existing
one dynamic also. For completeness, I made all remaining
parameters in the trajectory group be dynamic, as there is no
reason I can see not to do that.

としていることを想定してますので、unstableのときいにrvizの場合もraw_forceでなく校正済みのforceをいれたほうが同じプログラムで動くと思います（rvizのconfigにrfsensorとだけかくことになる。raw_rfsensorでなくて）
ちなみに、RobotHardwareから出している力センサの値とRMFOから出している力センサの値の違いは、
ざっくりいうとハンド・フットの重さを差し引いてるか、の違いです。ですので、
という特徴があります。後者は、もしRobothardwareからの生値ポートがなくなっても、どうしても欲しい人はRMFOからのポートの値にオフセットを足し込めば同等のものが得られます。
以上長文で失礼しましたがまとめますと、どれくらい使ってるかでポートには(A)、（B)の２種類あり、（A）はおっしゃる方法を考慮していく必要があると思っていまして、（B)は不要なようですので削除するのはいかがでしょうか、という提案になります。
ちなみに（A)向けにsubscribeに応じてポート接続をいいかんじにする方法を考えてみてますが、
といったかんじのことを考えてみています。
(A) 必要な人はいる(orいた)が、マニアックで全員必要でなさそうなもの(例:controlSwingSupportTime, 歩行指令に燗するもので、ゆう脚着地までの残り時間。
が使って以降あまりつかわれてなさそう)
(B) 機能的に他のものでカバーできるので不要と思われるもの(例:Unstable RTCでRFMO利用時の、RobotHardwareから得られる力の値)
一般論として、不要か不要でないか、は、結局不要だと思っても、そもそも最初に作った段階では必要だったわけで、今は必要ないように思って重、後で必要です、とかなったりするので、使えるようにはしておくのでいいと思うのと、
研究室に限った話では、この人が卒業したら誰も使わないなぁ、というのは、そもそも作らない／マージしない、というのもあると思います．
一般論として、不要か不要でないか、は、結局不要だと思っても、そもそも最初に作った段階では必要だったわけで、今は必要ないように思って重、後で必要です、とかなったりするので、使えるようにはしておくのでいいと思うのと、

の(A)は、そのポートがないと同じことをやるポート・方法の代替がないので、一時的に不要と思っても議論が必要だと思いますし、そもそもそれをマージしない、というところの判断もおっしゃるとおり重要だと思います。
(B)は、古い方法は完全にdeprecatedで新しいもので置き換えられるものでになるので、残しとくのにデメリットがないのであれば残しで良いと思いますが、今回は通信で実時間スレッドが圧迫される現象がでてきてしまったので、一考の余地がありなのかなと思いました。

pr_details_more: 現状
問題
解決
Stableなとき=RMFOがないとき
RosBridgeのraw_force_vectorから、RobotHardwareの力のデータポートの値をだす
RosBridgeのforce_vectorから、RobotHardwareの力のデータポートの値をだす
結果、ROSBridgeからのraw_force_vectorとforce_vectorがおなじものになる
Unstableなとき=RMFOがあるとき
ROSBridgeのforce_vectorから、RMFOの構成済み力のポートの値をだす
ROSBridgeのraw_force_vectorから、RobotHardwareの力のポートの値をだす
結果、ROSBridgeからのraw_force_vector, force_vectorは別の値がでる
Stableの場合はrfsensorなどにRobotHardwareからのポートがくる
Unstabelの場合はrfsensorなどにRMFOからのポートがくる
ハンド・フットの重さを特に設定してなければ、RobothardwareとRMFO同じ値になります
ハンドフットの重さパラメタは定数なので、RMFOの校正済みの値から姿勢を考慮しつつハンド・フットなどの重さを足し込むと、RobotHardwareの生値が再現できます。
初期起動時以降でポートのconnect自体をオンラインでやると、実時間スレッドを止めてしまう状況がある
ポート接続はいままでどおり初期起動時にやり、データポートの通信方法をpush型でなくpull型にするとできそう。ただし、pull型にしたらスレッドセーフでないかもしれなくて、
などを追っていく必要がありそう

pr_title: [WIP] [hrpsys_ros_bridge] Start joint trajectory at assigned timing
pr_contents: Depends on
Execution flow:
Currently, feedback from joint trajectory starts directly after getting goal, and stops when trajectory is completed.
of feedback (e.g.
) is calculated based on trajectory start time.
So when trajectory is in future,
starts from minus value.
I want to follow common specification of feedback, but specification is not uniformed...
＊ In all cases, joint trajectory is started on its time stamp, which is implemented in this PR.
NOTE: After this PR, time synchronization between PC bringing up ros bridge and PC publishing trajectory goal becomes very important.
これってノートPCから毎日違うロボットを動かそうとするときに，ロボットごとに時計が違ったら困りそうですが，その場合の正しい対処は何でしょうか．
これってノートPCから毎日違うロボットを動かそうとするときに，ロボットごとに時計が違ったら困りそうですが，その場合の正しい対処は何でしょうか．
違うロボットを使う場合は、そのロボットの時計に合わせるのがROSのルールになっています。
ntp/chronyのサーバをrosmasterと同じにすることで対応できます。
なので厳密には、ロボットを変えるたびにPCの設定を書き換えることになります。
なるほど，ちょっと面倒そうだけれど，”ROSのルール”と言われたら仕方ないのか．
横から失礼します．
参考までに，PR2ではchronyを使って，nictの時計に合わせたPCを1つ用意して，そのPCに対して各ロボットやラップトップなどをすべて合わせるようにしています．
(ラップトップはロボットに合わせている場合もあり)
なるほど，ちょっと面倒そうだけれど，”ROSのルール”と言われたら仕方ないのか．
ただ、実際はあまり時間ずれしてなくて、そのまま使えちゃうことの方が多いようにも思います。
現在、時刻が大きくずれていても:angle-vectorが実行できてしまうのは、hrpsys_ros_bridgeを使っているロボットだけかと思います。
参考までに，PR2ではchronyを使って，nictの時計に合わせたPCを1つ用意して，そのPCに対して各ロボットやラップトップなどをすべて合わせるようにしています．
(ラップトップはロボットに合わせている場合もあり)
今までちゃんと考えたことなかったですが、JSKのロボットを全て一つのPCに合わせるようにすれば、そのPCにラップトップを合わせるようにすればよいだけになるので、楽になってよさそうですね。
では、 stamp に 0 を入れると、受け取り次第動き出すようになっている。
これは、これまでのRosBridgeの動作と同じ動作をする。
時間同期が必要なかったら 0 を入れるという運用もありかもしれない。
When new trajectory comes, waiting trajectory should be cancelled, so current implementation may be correct.
However, I didn't come up with that situation and didn't test.
Back to WIP.

pr_title: [hrpsys_ros_bridge] chage RTC name of RangeROSBridge and PointCloudROSBridge
pr_contents: Currently name of RangeROSBridge component is RangeROSBridge0.rtc.
By this PR, the name of component is the same name as ROS nodename.
By this PR, the name of component is the same name as ROS nodename.
I haven't use this component, and I'm not familiar with it.
Could you explain why it is necessary, please?
i think component name can be changed by arguments
These components work for converting point cloud/lidar message from OpenRTM to ROS.
For the current implementation, RTC name of these components is PointCluoudRosBridge0, PointCluoudRosBridge1 ..., like that.
It is difficult to use if there are several components.
By this PR, RTC name is set as the same of ROS nodename.
So, we can change RTC name which is understandable, such as HEAD_DEPTH, FRONT_LIDER etc.
ImageSensorRosBridge does the same behavior as this PR.
Thank you for explanation. In which robot or environment, does this rtc used? In choreonoid simulation?

#!/bin/sh

export JSK_DIR=/opt/jsk
export LOG_DIR=/opt/jsk/var/log
export PATH=$JSK_DIR/bin:$PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/nextage-open/lib:/opt/jsk/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ## use libhrpIo.so in /opt/nextage-open/lib
#export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$JSK_DIR/share/nextage-open/lib:$JSK_DIR/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ## use libhrpIo.so in /opt/jsk/share/nextage-open
export RTCD_KILLNAME=rtcd

OS=`uname`
if [ "$OS" = "Linux" ]; then
  KILLALL="/usr/bin/killall -q"
elif [ "$OS" = "QNX" ]; then
  # On QNX many libraries requreid for hiro-nxo are installed via pkgsrc, which goes into /usr/pkg.
  export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/pkg/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
  KILLALL=/bin/slay
fi

#
# loop for rtcd
#
mkdir -p $LOG_DIR
$KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME

while :; do
    /opt/nextage-open/bin/unlock_iob

    if [ -f $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log ]; then
        rm $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log
    fi

    DATESTRING=`date +%Y%m%d%H%M%S`
    ln -s $LOG_DIR/rtcd-$DATESTRING.log $LOG_DIR/rtcd.log
    rtcd -f /opt/jsk/etc/HIRONX/hrprtc/rtcdRobotMode.conf > $LOG_DIR/rtcd-$DATESTRING.log 2>&1

    /usr/bin/env sleep 1
    $KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME
    /usr/bin/env sleep 1
    $KILLALL -9 $RTCD_KILLNAME
done

pr_title: Program for calculating the linear drag coefficient in all 6 directions
pr_contents: Great work on this program! After some small changes I hope to see it running on the Sub to model this and help to improve our controls!
In addition to my comments, the program should go in
and info should be added to the README of that package explaining what the program does and how to use it.
This is exciting! Jason and I talked about doing something like this for a long time.
Some things to consider:
As

mentioned, the right way to do this is to formulate it as a statistical regression problem. Not only would you get better results with less painstaking experiments, you'd also become an omnipotent god of estimation theory in the process.
However, MIL is 50% about doing things right, and 50% about doing things right enough. So in the style of your approach here, might I suggest the following:
It sounds like the real goal is to get a simplified drag model that can help compute a feedforward term in your controller. I.e. your PD controller will output some wrench based on feedback,
the drag coefficients you found here times the current twist, in hopes of cancelling the effect of drag on the sub.

So, just skip ahead and add that term to your controller right now with a wild guess at the drag coefficients (all zero is a fine guess). Then, instead of commanding wrenches for experimenting (which wont stop the sub from moving along axes it shouldn't for the current test), you should command twists through your controller. So if you're testing the sub's forward motion, command a twist that is only nonzero for forward linear velocity.

As usual, you'll see a nice controlled straight line motion that rejects most bobbing and other disturbances... but also as usual, the velocity that the sub achieves won't be the exact velocity you commanded! It will be off by some amount, because your feedforward term has the wrong drag coefficient. Tweak the drag coefficient until the sub's velocity matches what you commanded. Repeat for each axis.
If tweaking by hand seems tedious, code up your tweaking process so it happens automatically. Congratulations, you made an adaptive controller.
Anyway, nice work so far!

This email explains how to find docs for fiducial floor follow mode of the Magni robot.
To see the readme that discusses this code you can go to
then select Branch pulldown on that page to be 'floor_follow'.
Then go into fiducial_follow still on that webpage and the readme is there.
A second 'customer facing document' of less detail is online here:
I suggest you look at BOTH to learn as much as possible about this mode of operation.
HOW TO GET REAL CODE TO RUN IT:

We hope to have the code merged to our master branch in mid Feb 2020.  At this time two repositories must be put into ~/catkin_ws/src and then the normal  catkin_make must be done from  ~/catkin_ws  before this code can be used.
Clone these two repositories from ~/catkin_ws/src
git clone
git clone
For each of these new directories in ~/catkin_ws/src you must cd into it then type   'git checkout floor_follow'
After that from ~/catkin_ws  you must do the  'catkin_make'
Doing the above things will very much help to get going.
You will not be able to actually use or test this code without a new bracket that is in development and likely not ready till earliest date of mid Feb 2020
Once we have proper camera mounting we can then start to play with the code on a real robot.

pr_title: Fix missing clusters split while jumping back
pr_contents: ScanProcessor::splitConnected(float thresh) currently only consider the situation that range increase suddenly but ignore sudden decrease. When  sudden decrease occurs, it will jump to "else" to "++s_rest". If range is far enough, "expand" will be 1 or 2, nothing happen. But  if range is very close, it may miss a jumping back， which will led to incorrect clusters split.
I think we just need to add a "std::abs(float)" to the "if"

leg_detector->void pairLegs(). At the second loop that "Attempt to pair up legs with no id", did you forget to change "closest_dist" to "d" when a pair of better legs appear. If we don't do that, it  will only remember the first pair and every thing else we do will be forgot. And I think we just need to loop "leg2" from "leg1 + 1", cause the distance is scalar not vector.

There are several packages failing, some are warranted failures but for some the check seems a bit too restrictive. For example the comparison is made regardless of the parameter type, for string for example it may not make sense to do a comparison (arguably it may not make much sense to give a range to a string parameter in the first place..).

Some packages seem to set out of range values purposefully, I guess it's to reflect the "uninitialized" state. Though to confirm I guess we should reach out to the maintainers of these packages to see if it's a valid assumption.

I use the DEPENDS keyword. Without it, you have the normal behavior.

pr_contents: the value of the integrator is an important part of the state of a PID controller. I only tested this on groovy, but I don't know whether it's appropriate to add any new features to groovy at this point. Either way, this commit should merge cleanly with Hydro too.
This was useful is discovering
Sorry I'm not very familiar with controls. What would change visually on the robot if this is implemented?
Also, the .msg file will have a different checksum which will cause big errors for users of this node. (Causing it to be non-backward compatible)
This change, apart from breaking the "binary"-ish compatibility you mentioned, doesn't affect any behavior on the robot.
The joint/velocity controllers use the
class in the
package, which is a PID controller. One of the things in the

class is a field which accumulates (integrates) the error, which is an important quantity for the PID controller. And to tune or debug a PID controller, it's nice to have access to its full state, including the value of the integrator.
As far as I know, the purpose of the

is for debugging.  This PR just makes available some extra debugging information. It is unnatural that the JointControllerState publishes every other single piece of state of the PID controller (all the gains, the derivative) but not the integral.
I don't know enough to know how bad it is to change
files the change-the-hash way. It's not the most backwards incompatible since no fields were removed or renamed. But it does require all distributions of ROS to have the same message file.
I just did a search and found some code using it for what appears to be something other than debugging

pr_title: Use OMPL for global path planning for global_planner
pr_contents: This PR integrates
into global_planner.
Most of the previous
has been written from the ground up, making it quite hard to modify the planning algorithm itself.

Having OMPL as a planner backend will give more versatility to add / modify the path planning algorithm and give access to the various planners that are available in OMPL. Moreover, given that ompl do not depend on map representations, this could potentially enable the ability to use different map representations for different use cases.
A lot have the structure has been used following
Currently depends on
and will rebase once merged. Was first proposed in
Nice work! I am one of the OMPL developers. I see that RRT* is made the default planner. Is this the fastest in your testing? Note that we have added a

that you can use to have RRT* terminate upon convergence rather than wait for a timeout. Running a feasible planner (e.g., RRTConnect) followed by path simplification often works "well enough" and can be much faster, so make sure to give that a try, too.

Finally, you may also want to experiment with different state spaces. I can imagine that high-speed drone flight kinodynamic constraints become very important. OMPL has several kinodynamic planners that, once you implement a steering function, could also work well. A reasonable approximation of the kinodynamic constraints can be obtained by modeling the drone as a Dubins vehicle or Reeds-Sheep vehicle with translation in the Z direction. We have successfully used this in a collaboration with the University of Girona for AUVs. See
and
. This can be done by creating your own custom StateSpace (e.g., a CompoundStateSpace comprised of DubinsStateSpace and a RealVectorStateSpace).

Thanks for the insights and pointers! I am using RRT* simply as a example. There is a lot to improve, but the current state I would be satisfied would be to have a path searching global planner(Such as RRT*) with polynomial path smoothing.

I would definitely want to move towards the planning with dynamic constraints. This is becoming more and more of an issue not just for the dynamic constraints but also for the limited sensor range vehicles normally have.
Most of the leg work that needs to be done is integrating ompl with the PX4 flight stack, but hopefully we are almost there

I have quite bad experiences while using this for mapping, and I found that one of the reasons is because of outdated scans. So I tried reducing the queue for laser scans to one, so unprocessed scans don't accumulate and we always use the latest available.
I added an extra check on how old latest scan is: scan_tolerance parameter. A negative value disables it.
I don't understand deeply how gmapping works, so feel free to discard this pull request if it's misguided or useless.

Could you elaborate on what you mean by "bad experiences"? Obviously, if the scan gets old enough, TF won't have data to transform it, which should just throw a ROS_ERROR message, but not really cause problems.
I would suggest not changing the size of the queue mid-release-cycle, as it could have unintended side effects. It should be possible to add a new parameter for the queue size instead.

Big jumps in robot pose due to "wrong" scan matching. I quote the wrong because it's wrong from the omniscient RViz point of view but not for the algorithm. I tried tweaking parameters to make gmapping relay more on odometry instead of accepting any matching, but failed.

In more detail: I use a turtlebot, so the "laser" is very narrow. So when it faces featureless areas like walls, it gets easily confused. That's specially true in simulation, where the environment is normally very featureless, or in test environments without typical furniture (as in this video
). I wonder if the algorithm would need an ad-hoc rule to avoid corrections (specially big jumps) when matching a featureless scan... as it does when the scan is fully nan or inf.

I think there's no such a control by now, as current implementation uses Transformer::transformPose, who doesn't control timings (not 100% sure on this, sorry). At least I have never seen the WARN "Failed to compute odom pose, skipping scan", but I have verified that after a map update, the 5 stocked scans get processed, with the oldest one being a second old.

pr_title: simple modification of min_distance In consideration of obstacles
pr_contents: If there is obstacles between robot and fronter, then |p1-p2| can't represent the true distance. We can introduce the search depth into the distance, because the nearer frontier will be found at earlier iteration.  So we simply add a distance_cnt * resolution to the original distance to make it close to the true distance between robot and frontier in map.

pr_title: Fixed transformation error for centered_laser_pose_ computation
pr_contents: fixed transformation error for centered_laser_pose_ computation in case of laser mounted upside down
tf::createQuaternionFromRPY() takes fixed angles as input such that angle_center is not affected by the 180 deg roll
LGTM, but not 100% sure if this does not break existing users, do you have any simulation environment  that we can check this ?
This change only affects users where angle_center != 0 and the scanner is mounted upside down. I believe we are one of the first to encounter this case.

We tested this on one of our MP-400 at Neobotix which is fitted with a new scanner for testing purposes. This scanner doesn't follow the ROS convention and thus has a angle_center of over 100 deg. When we mounted the scanner normally we could build maps no problem, but when we mounted it upside down we got major issues trying to build a map, everything was rotated and it was a big mess. However in RVIZ it looked just fine in both cases (using odom as reference), so the problem had to be in gmapping.
With this fix we can build maps just fine even when the scanner is mounted upside down.
Hope that helps.

Most of these are already included in the TF library, boost, and OpenCV.

Some of them are implemented in OpenCV and others, but I think we should proceed with libraries to reduce dependencies using wrappers etc. Functions such as OpenCV are low-level APIs, and there are various common codes to use these things. We need to abstract a little more for Autoware.
And many of them are not implemented in these libraries, and cooperation between libraries reduces the readability of the code.
In Apollo, these libraries are very carefully made and commonly used. Even if I make such a library from now on, nobody uses it, so I think that it should be prepared as soon as possible.
In the future I will also implement table-based sin, cos etc.

I would agree with you if we were to add them as new dependencies. That would be indeed a huge load for just a few classes. However, we use ROS, which already includes these libraries. Moreover, these are widely tested, constantly maintained, and very likely free of bugs. If you care about readability, why not build wrappers around them instead of writing from scratch?

ok, let's assume you implemented it. It took me ten seconds to find an existing library, maintained by large team of developers, that implemented all that. It's a problem when the first instinct is to add new code instead of relying on existing tools. For example, do you think we need our own implementation of a Vector3? Vector3d is a Eigen wrapper. Certainly, if something is set as the default, wrapper will not be needed.
Ok. Kalman filter and table based sin cos are necessary to develop ros node. What should these be done?
From the viewpoint of the library user, I think that it is useful an abstraction layer of math processing for the following reasons.
I feel that an using alias is better than wrapper class for vector type. My opinion is as follows.

If you use Eigen for internal implementation, define abstract vector types as Eigen type aliases and functions as Eigen function wrapper. And add your own implementation or other library functions for abstract vector types. Finally, support wrappers for other library types.
what do you mean by Kalman Filter? that would depend on the sensors and purpose of the algorithm itself. Also why do you need a table of sin and cos?
what do you mean by Kalman Filter? that would depend on the sensors and purpose of the algorithm itself. Also why do you need a table of sin and cos?
Thank you.

About Kalman Filter: you are correct. However, the formulas of the Kalman filter are reusable because they can be made generalized kalman filter library. For example, we are currently developing ekf for localization estimation. Here, we have implemented a Kalman filter library that can be used generically. We want to use this library with mot (multi object tracking).

Table of sin and cos: Calculation of sin function is expensive because calculation is Taylor expansion. The sin function is very often used in MPC, Particle Filer, Local path palanner, etc. In addition, they generally need to run at high frequency, which makes the computational cost a bottleneck. There is still reasons, in the past experience, this is absolutely necessary.
From the viewpoint of the library user, I think that it is useful an abstraction layer of math processing for the following reasons.

pr_quotes: I cannot see any tests for the new functions, can you add them?
I put it in the todo list, so I planned to check it when I finish. Would it have been better to issue a PR after the test?
can you explain why do you need to add these ?
Most of these are already included in the TF library, boost, and OpenCV.
I know there is such libraries, so it is not reimplemented. Basically it is implemented as a wrapper.
However, because the basic algorithm necessary for autonomous driving is insufficient by itself, partly I scratched.

example, a lot of epsilon is defined to make a floating point comparison, or a bug occurs because an appropriate comparison is not done. What I implemented is such a basic function, but it is not provided by the library (numerical comparision).

The part to be maintained is a wrapper necessary for using with Autoware. If it does not exist, inconvenience of various dependency relations and writing style occurs, a bug is born and maintenance becomes difficult.

For example, there are various vector libraries that provide the same functionality, such as openCV, Eigen and ignition, and because everyone uses different libraries, the dependency is getting worse. (
(comment))
We will be in trouble if OpenCV becomes unusable due to version upgrade, porting problem, license problem or etc..
what do you mean by Kalman Filter? that would depend on the sensors and purpose of the algorithm itself. Also why do you need a table of sin and cos?
From the viewpoint of the library user, I think that it is useful an abstraction layer of math processing for the following reasons.
I feel that an using alias is better than wrapper class for vector type. My opinion is as follows.

If you use Eigen for internal implementation, define abstract vector types as Eigen type aliases and functions as Eigen function wrapper. And add your own implementation or other library functions for abstract vector types. Finally, support wrappers for other library types.
Thank you.

About Kalman Filter: you are correct. However, the formulas of the Kalman filter are reusable because they can be made generalized kalman filter library. For example, we are currently developing ekf for localization estimation. Here, we have implemented a Kalman filter library that can be used generically. We want to use this library with mot (multi object tracking).

OK, I understand what you mean by KF now. Nevertheless, if you are planning on re-using the KF for other non-localization modules, as mot. I don't think the current placement of the KF library is clear enough for new Autoware users to use.

KF is used by many modules. MOT just wants to use it right now, and in the future, there are many modules that use KF, such as white line estimateion, IMU bias estimation, path prediction and so on. Is this not enough?
pr_details_more: add inside and outside judgment algorithm
add search algorithm using kd-tree
add 2d/3d vector
add lightweight random number generator (xorshift128)
add unit converter
add float comparision
Add interporation
Add table based sin cos
Add converter between ros msg and autoware math library
Add kalman filter
Add integral function
Add convex-hull algorithm in Polygon
Add hungarian algorithm
Tests
Documentation
add license
Basically it is implemented as a wrapper. However, because the basic algorithm necessary for autonomous driving is insufficient by itself, partly I scratched.

Many nodes of Autoware call algorithms implemented in OpecCV, PCL, etc., and many of the code is a complicated procedure for using the library. In order to improve readability, we need to abstract a little more for Autoware.

The current Autoware software has individual nodes relying too much on various libraries. For example, suppose you only wanted to use linear interpolation but rely on OpenCV. We will be in trouble if OpenCV becomes unusable due to version upgrade, porting problem, license problem or etc.. If it is made into a library, it can be solved by re-implementing the linear interpolation unit.
In terms of portability, readability, and testing, algorithms and programs as ROS should be separated to some extent.
Currently, some packages have their own implementation of math processing. Extract them and make it available from other packages.
Need functions that are not included in the existing library and frequently used utility function that combines low-level functions.

It's annoying to convert to library type such as from geometry_msgs, vector_map_msgs, or PCL to Eigen, OpenCV, or Boost. Type conversions should be isolated by wrapper since they are unrelated to the algorithm.

As a solution
・ (Recommended) Use VLP-32c etc.

・Fusion Odometry, IMU, GNSS with EKF. We are developing this feature.

Thank you for your reply! Now efk localizer will use the matching score evaluation indicator for fusion?
ekf_localizer receives the geometry_msgs::PoseWithCovarianceStamped message and evaluates it using its covariance.
Now ndt_slam uses inverse of Hessian matrix for covariance.
However, I also think that the proposal is to change covariance by matching_score.
Fusion with ekf_localizer is still an experimental feature and may not work well yet.
We are still considering how to make covariance.
You are right, but do you have a good way to solve the covariance matrix based on the current match score (0-1)? I think the Hessian matrix still needs to be used.

Thanks, I fixed the typo:
without this PR, collision object moves when fetch moves.
with this PR, collision objects are associated with map frame, so that objects do not move when fetch moves.
Thank you. I understand.
It seems very important when we want to use MoveIt! collision object with navigation.

maybe we need to support adding collision object with specific frame in moveit for the future.
Recently there sometimes happens that base_laser device cannot be recognized by ROS node.
By conversation with Mr.Uchimi that we should monitor that device, I wrote a program of monitoring devices including base_laser.
I will check this program works well with PR1040 and refine.
Advised by Prof.Okada, I will utilize /diagnostics topic or sanity_check to make a system general with several robots.
I will utilize TopicPublishedChecker of
I will add function of monitorTopicIsPublished in
With checkTopicIsPublished, we can check the topic once, but I want to monitor (check always) the topic, so I think we need monitorTopicIsPublished.
I will implement that we can set callback function in monitorTopicIsPublished which is called when the topic is death. I want to hear your opinion before implementation.
Change parameters to enable recovery_behavior.
This can be useful when robot is stuck by obstacles.
Still testing with real robot.
Why you disabled at
and re-enabled?
Why I disabled?
According to
, the default value of
is
, which means recovery_behavior is disabled by default.
To notice this fact easily, I added a comment in
Why I (re-)enabled?
The problem is how to deal with moving obstacles such as human.
Assume that human is standing 2 meters in front of the robot, and robot rotates 180 degrees in place.
Then a user commands the robot to go to the place the human was standing.
In this case, even if the human went away, the robot fails to plan to reach the goal, since the robot cannot observe that the human has already gone.
The robot has to rotate in place to update costmap, so I enabled recovery_behavior.
With this PR, move_base itself will give up on going to the target spot in some case.
If you want to retry forever, you must control from upper level such as euslisp
pr_details: Why I disabled?
According to
, the default value of
is
, which means recovery_behavior is disabled by default.
To notice this fact easily, I added a comment in
Why I (re-)enabled?
The problem is how to deal with moving obstacles such as human.
Assume that human is standing 2 meters in front of the robot, and robot rotates 180 degrees in place.
Then a user commands the robot to go to the place the human was standing.
In this case, even if the human went away, the robot fails to plan to reach the goal, since the robot cannot observe that the human has already gone.
The robot has to rotate in place to update costmap, so I enabled recovery_behavior.

This system is a little complicated for shell beginners like me, because there are two shell evaluations before fetch's bringup (install_upstart.sh -> jsk-fetch-startup.conf -> fetch_bringup.launch).
FYI
jsk-fetch-startup.conf of previous version:
pr_code:
/etc/ros/indigo/jsk-fetch-startup.conf
description "spawn jsk bringup nodes for fetch"
# use default log dir: yamaguchi & s-kitagawa (2019/04/18)
# env ROS_LOG_DIR=/var/log/ros

start on roscore_is_up
stop on roscore_is_down

respawn

# add ROSCONSOLE_FORMAT: s-kitagawa (2019/10/03)
env AUDIO_DEVICE="alsa_output.usb-1130_USB_AUDIO-00-AUDIO.analog-stereo"
env ROSCONSOLE_FORMAT="[${severity}] [${time}] [${node}:${logger}]: ${message}"

# enable usb speaker if available
pre-start script
    # launch by fetch user: yamaguchi & s-kitagawa (2019/04/18)
    # exec su ros -c "pactl set-default-sink $AUDIO_DEVICE || true"
    exec su fetch -c "pactl set-default-sink $AUDIO_DEVICE || true"
end script

    # launch by fetch user: yamaguchi & s-kitagawa (2019/04/18)

is required, which was merged but not yet released.

pr_title: Add cluster point indices label filter
pr_contents: Talking to
and
we realized that we do not actually have any good methods to extract cluster_points from
with matching labels
getting only pet bottle objects from 73b2_kitchen recognition node. So we decided to implement a node to do that:
Other approaches such as using
are not only redundant, but also many times only cover the first label instance. Subscribing and filtering in eus is also not safe regarding synchronization.
The usage / design of this node is questionable, so am open to discussions / suggestions.

Specially regarding cases where we want to get multiple types of objects, was also thinking it might be a good idea to set a namespace and a label list and have filtered results under that namespace (using the label name). Something like:
id_value: [7,9,13]
namespace: 'test'
Btw regarding sample / test code, was thinking on making use of the hsr bag file on
, but for that we would need to have it on the
repo.
I see. Should I mv the bag file to
on
or make another PR?
If you can move the bag file (and the play_rosbag xml) to the jsk_pcl_ros_utils in the same PR that would be appreciated!
OK. I moved the bag file to
Added sample and test code!
NOTE: this requires
to be merged first

I tested it with the test code (using moveTo with move config (= speed selector)) below.

topic. I created only pepper condition now.

pr_code:
#! /usr/bin/env python                                                                                                                            
"""                                                                                                                                               
This example is based on the moveTo method sample in http://doc.aldebaran.com/2-4/naoqi/motion/control-walk-api.html#control-walk-api.            
"""
import qi
import argparse
import sys
import math

def main(session):
    motion_service  = session.service("ALMotion")
    x  = 0.4
    y  = 0
    theta  = math.pi/2
    motion_service.moveTo(x, y, theta, [["MaxVelXY", 0.35],["MaxVelTheta", 0.2]])
    #0.4 / 0.35 = 1.1                                                                                                                            
    # (pi/2) / 0.2 = 7.85                                                                                                                         
    # => pepper moves for 7.85s                                                                                                                  

    # if x = 0.4, y = 0.1 => pepper moves for 1.1 s                                                                                               

if __name__ == "__main__":
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument("--ip", type=str, default="127.0.0.1",
                        help="Robot IP address. On robot or Local Naoqi: use '127.0.0.1'.")
    parser.add_argument("--port", type=int, default=9559,
                        help="Naoqi port number")

    args = parser.parse_args()
    session = qi.Session()
    try:
        session.connect("tcp://" + args.ip + ":" + str(args.port))
    except RuntimeError:
        print ("Can't connect to Naoqi at ip \"" + args.ip + "\" on port " + str(args.port) +".\n"
               "Please check your script arguments. Run with -h option for help.")
        sys.exit(1)
    main(session)

pr_contents: do you still need this? if so please resolve conflicts.
I need topic message type of pose with string label in element_matching_pose_estimation
in order to consider the matching of robot hand and object grasping point. (label of pose corresponds to hand name or object grasping point name.)
One solution is this PR and another is
Please give opinions.
I'll send PR of rviz plugins for visualizing topic after message is merged.
Pros of this PR
・ Meaning of topic is correct compared with
（I'd like to represent POSE of hand or grasping point, not TRANSFORMATION.
Contents of them are same but variable names are not same. position and orientation is used for pose, and translation and rotation is used for transformation.)
Pros of
・ Only one message is added newly.
In my estimation program, three elements are considered, edge, polygon, and points.
If we have these three elements as topic, we can subscribe those topics with synchronize message filter (In my understanding, tf topic cannot be subscribed with synchronization).
I think this is most easy-to-understand implementation.
But I also agree that adding message, topic, etc.. with same function make the system complicated.

As I write the following, even if I use tf instead of adding new pose or transformation message, I still need to add new message which represents frame_id array (which does not contain pose or transformation) to tell which tf corresponds to grasping point.
If it is OK, I'll consider that policy.
Pros of LabeledPoseArray (this PR) or TransfromArrray (
) "topic"
・ able to synchronize
Pros of tf
・ No new pose or transform type is necessary (but I think StringArray.msg become necessary newly to tell which tf frame is grasping point. Is that OK.)
I talked with
in person, and the conclusion is that we just wait for his research progress, because there is many things that should be done (and he wants to do).
Currently his system is composed of 2 fades
and what he wants to do next is to pass information of context and geometric restraint condition from the real robot to the matching system for example:
so I think (he may also think) that his system needs another process before finding element pair,
and pass the restraint condition as ROS message or euslisp function argument:
This PR is an example of geometric restraint condition about 3D point, (robot-hand and an element must be in the same place).
So I'd like to add following message to jsk_recognition_msgs and use this for grasping point matching.
This covers all element types
How do you think
Element.msg
ElementCorrespondence.msg
I forgot type of element, and added it to previous comment.
Is this passed from 0 (
) to 1 (matching finder)?
Yes.
Or some nodes (including main.l) publish this topic, and merge before subscribed in matching finder.
For example, we need new node to estimate object contact state from robot sensor, and that node should publish the correspondence of following condition.
target object is put on the plane which is located on the same plane with robot's foot.
For example, we need new node to estimate object contact state from robot sensor, and that node should publish the correspondence of following condition.
target object is put on the plane which is located on the same plane with robot's foot.
Ok, I think this is fine for now.
BTW, in above example, without any information of restriction condition, you can't use in matching finder, right?
Because the polygon can exactly match, be on the same plane, parallel or vertical, and there is no information about that.
What is the assumed restrict condition in your current system? for example:
point and point: in the same point
把持点：緩い把持なので手先の姿勢は考慮しない
pose and pose: in the same point
把持点：硬い把持なので手先の姿勢も考慮する
point and line: in the same line
把持点：パイプをゆくる掴んでいるのでパイプに沿って動く方向は拘束しない
point and polygon: in the same plane
物体の頂点が地面の上にある
line and line: in the same line
ドアのヒンジ側のエッジが壁にくっついている
polygon and polygon: in the same plane
物体の面が地面の上にある
BTW, in above example, without any information of restriction condition, you can't use in matching finder, right?
Because the polygon can exactly match, be on the same plane, parallel or vertical, and there is no information about that.
I can't understand this meaning. Could you explain more?
Do you mean rotation-axis and translation-axis in euslisp IK? I think it would be useful so I need to add that field to ElementCorrespondence.msg
Do you mean rotation-axis and translation-axis in euslisp IK
Yes.
And you may also want to specify degree and distance if the axis.
What do you think about these?

pr_title: Added a feedforward term for velocity commands in PID loop
pr_contents: In reference to
's comments last year:
and
Unfortuantly these changes were never made and when the PR was split up and refactored it was forgotten.
Running this on Baxter, I saw huge improvements.
friendly ping?
I'd be interested in knowing how well this patch behaves in the face of large disturbances.
, have you tried holding Baxter's arms so the tracking error grows significantly, and then let go?, are you satisfied with the behavior in such circumstances?.

If there's someone out there also using the velocity backend of this controller, would you mind giving this one a test?. I'm concerned that people already using it might have to change their existing PID gains specification if this patch gets merged.
I have not tried that, will test next time I'm using hardware.

I am still using this fix on Baxter and our new robot and its been over a year. Not having a feedforward term is really detrimental to the performance in my experience. I think this should be merged into Jade
To put my two cents in, if this patch is merged I would also strongly consider adding this to indigo, since that is the LTS.
Perhaps now is the right time to merge this into the jade release?
My only reservation here is that the PR might change behavior. Have you tried both alternatives (old and new) with the same set of gains, on hardware?.
Yes, it does change behavior. But that is why we release it into Indigo. Its a bug that I introduced when I implemented it a couple years ago, and I fixed it over a year ago, and still it remains.
Currently, however, I am not using any velocity controllers so its hard for me to test it since I'm now using ros_control for other robots.

This is a proposition to integrate a mecanum_drive_controller in ros_controllers. This controller computes the wheels velocities given a desired twist and computes the odometry given the observed wheels velocity.
This PR relates to issue
:  Making room for mecanum_drive_controller.
There is no unit test yet.
Also it is not clear yet which twists are expected as input (desired twist) and output (odometry twist). This question is raised in issue
and in ROS answers:
This code still needs further testing, unit tests and review. I will try to do this when pressure cools down a bit :)
You can find plenty of tests in diff_drive_controller/test, feel free to refactor them. I'm sure most of them will come very useful to you!
((It might make sense after you have them to run a coverage tool to see which parts of the code are not being excersized during the tests.))
You are right, this is exactely how I plan to proceed. Only need to get out of my rush to consolidate all this. Thanks ;)
Please let us know when the code stops being in flux and is in shape for a review. Adding tests would be a big plus.

As for the unit tests I agree with you and this is my intention. As for the review, code has been rather stable for a week or two now, but I am still undergoing a few hand tests before making things officially for review ;)
I'm interested in this, and may be able to contribute to tests and verification in the new year.

Regarding the simulation, I recommend not to use gazebo for mecanum wheels. I spent a lot of time (I mean A LOT ;)) only to realize gazebo is not quite ready yet for the scenario.
Basically you have 2 choices for simulating mecanum wheels:

The solution shown in the link you sent does not simulate the mecanum wheels at all: it is only a kinematic trick allowing to get good looking visuals, but unfortunately you do not get a proper mecanum wheels behavior.

Because of this we decided to use vrep rather than gazebo, and... well, this turned out to be an excellent decision. Vrep really rocks and does feel professional. I have coded a ros_control / vrep back-end example (equivalent to ros-indigo-gazebo-ros-control, but for vrep rather than gazebo), and it is available here:

on our prototype

units, and we're very happy with it. One thing to note is that it's definitely hard-coded for the rectangular case, and I wonder if the name of the controller should reflect that (ie, that it is not suitable for a platform with six mecanum wheels, or three, or whatever).
Also, have you coalesced on an ideal approach to simulating mecanum wheels in Gazebo? We've not really been satisfied with any of the existing options.
Hello Mike,

And thanks for your feedback. You are right, the fixed number of wheels the controller can handle is not clear from its name (and you certainly have to dig into the doc and code to know about it). I need to come back to the controller's code in a few weeks so this observation may lead to
Now as for simulating mecanum wheels inside gazebo, there are several ways to do it: 1)
: this has turned out to be very resource intensive and is not very stability, or 2)
such as

: this is the method I decided to go for. I have found using 2) within gazebo required code modifications of gazebo really deeply rooted and too time consuming to meet our R&D constraints. The restriction inside gazebo is described
and reported

. The workaround I have found is to use vrep (after using it for a few months now, I can say this simulation software highly deserves attention, it really rocks) and the trick mentioned in 2). I have shared some code bridging vrep and ros_controllers
(this allows me to use the
in a clean and straightforward way).

Now maybe you allow me to take advantage of your message to ask you another question. The mecanum_drive_controller takes a cartesian velocity as input (i.e. the command input in the mecanum_drive_controller is a twist). Now what we want to do is to have our mobile robot follow a cartesian path. We can sample our path in such a way that each sample contains the desired cartesian position, twist (and even acceleration but we do not use the acceleration) of the mobile robot - the desired cartesian path is obviously on a plane. In order to transform the desired path into a velocity command (i.e. the input of the
) we use the following command law (this is C++ code):
[i] * desiredVelocity_inBody[i] + kp_[i] * errorPosition_inBody[i] + kv_[i] * errorVelocity_inBody[i];_
that is the twist command is made up out of the desired twist + feedback on the position and velocity errors.

This command law turns out not to be as stable as I had hoped. Hence my question: what method do you use in order to have your robot follow a path precisely? Do you use a command law such as mine, or do you have another method?

by Mackenzie; although some signs differ on

on Mackenzie's model, and it seems you don't follow the same wheels enumeration as him, as in
. According to it, the name mecanum drive looks appropriate to me.

And to answer your last question, the reason why there is a frame transformation in the odometry is because the odometry computes a body velocity (i.e. a body twist) but a world position (well the position is actually not expressed in the world frame but in the /odom frame, which can be different).

Also, have you experimented with the quality of the odometry? I have a large drift which I am not happy with: a few centimers on a 10s movement - could be due to the fact I use simulation at 40Hz only. Can you let me know if the results you obtain with the odometry are good enough in your case?
--- UPDATE ---

The drift was actually caused by the feedback using odometry measures (there is not much that can be done here: drift is a well know problem of odometry). So I have double checked and I am now confident that the IK and FK bits of code are fine.

I have thought about a workaround to get useful unit tests despite of not being able to simulate mecanum wheels in gazebo. We could actually design a robot using standard wheels (rather than mecanum wheels) and unit test the mecanum IK and FK (odometry) on this scene.

Running the scene and the unit test would not show that the controller is working (the behavior would obviously be nonesense) but this unit test could actually show that the behavior of the code does not change over time... which is actually the reason of being unit tests.
We know that the controller works, if we enforce its behavior does not change over time then we get what we want out of the unit tests, no?

Note that I'm working on trying to simulate these wheels in Gazebo using directional friction. I believe it's pretty close to functional, though there is some remaining oddball behaviour that I was hoping to get some assistance from the Gazebo devs on:

Can't you get some basic testing in place without a dynamic simulator?. Something like comparing controller outputs to known correct results?. Some white-box (implementation aware) testing could maybe exercise different known code paths, or validate different configurations (wheel placement, size, etc.). I typically like to unit test the guts (actual computation) in simple, very targeted tests, and then test the whole system (ROS interfaces) in a higher-level, but less exhaustive integration rostest.

I really wanted the directional friction solution to work, and sunk a nontrivial amount of time on it, but all that was ~3 years ago and under Gazebo 7. It's possible that the situation is different under Gazebo 8 or 9— if anyone's interested to pick up the work again, you can start here:

Basically just switch the plugins in the URDF over to the commented-out ones, launch the sim, and give it a series of twists that command it to move in X and Y. Generally I found that the "strafe" commands would seem to work correctly in either direction for a metre or two and then it would seemingly go unstable and spin out of control. I strongly suspect that the plugin was not correctly updating the directional friction as the wheel turned, but without a reliable way to visualize the friction vector in realtime, it seems like a dead end to try to fix it.

pr_title: Fix missing trajectory segment bug, removed deprecated code
pr_contents: This has the fix created by
as discussed in
where he says:

I looked at the joint_trajectory_controller code and I found that the start time of the first trajectory segment is calculated using the previous period. This might cause that the start time of the first trajectory is later than the next sample time when the previous period is longer(even 1us) than the current period because of the jitter. And this leads to the above error.
I ran his fix overnight with continuous trajectory interruption and the error did not occur again.
I've also removed a code block that was intended to be removed in indigo, and I added a section for optionally measuring message latency in actionlib using compiler flags.
Thank you for your quick work.
I'm not sure that the threshold is reasonably small or it should be smaller. I chose period because I didn't want to include any extra magic parameter.

pr_title: fix behavior for multi-turn revolute joints
pr_contents: Previously, the behavior of revolute joints was unexpected when
the joint limits extended beyond [-pi, pi] due to unwrapping
happening in a few places in the angles package, which was called
from the joint position controller. This PR checks to see if the
range of motion extends beyond [-pi, pi] and, if so, goes directly
to the (clamped) target, rather than trying to unwrap the current
or target angles to find the shortest path.

Could you show me a situation where the behavior is unexpected?

Any measured angle from Gazebo that is outside of -pi to pi is forced to be within that range. This is a problem for Sawyer, as the seventh joint has a range -4.15 to 4.15 rad. I can handle fixing Sawyer, but we should address this for the larger community.

to handle larger joint limits properly?

This is the distillation of
to a pull request that has been tested on a robot with 3 sensors. Much of the initial development was done by
, with design refinements and bugfixes added.
Many of the changes (ie,
) were written to support the "simple" default clearer, which should be
the same as the original (current) implementation. Now, using a parameter flag (
), the new algorithm can be applied instead, which creates a volumetric cache around each clearing sensor to apply to the costmap.
The cache is used to speed up the implementation, and should have larger impact with more points to clear. We profiled the initial implementation, shown
, but have not profiled the latest code. However, we have used it in practice on a live robot and there are no qualitative speed issues.

One overall issue with such a commit such as this is that there is currently no simple way to perform unit/integration tests to establish its correctness (this applies to many components of the nav stack). One suggestion would agree upon a test bagfile, as well as test launch and parameter files, so that all components of the execution could be properly controlled. This seems like a larger issue that would need more work/consensus, but I think it would be worth the effort.
I know this is a large change but I encourage testing and consideration into the main branches.

pr_title: Adding "start clearing range" to the Obstacle Layer.
pr_contents: Start clearing range is the minimal distance at which a sensor can see an obstacle. This is useful for all stereo based sensor (like RGBD and stereo cameras). Obstacles  will not be cleared between the sensor and this range.

I code this patch because I encounter the follwing problem. I have a mobile robot with an RGBD sensor moving in a place where there is a lot of shelfs (or low table). When the robot is far of this objects, there is no problem, they are seend as obstacles. But if the robot go close of this objects, they are cleared as the robot move...
If you want further explanation ask me, I can create a video With and Without my patch.
This is half of
Yes this look like to be the half of

. But my patch works for all data source (not only LaserScan). I think this is important to introduce a new parameter in the source properties rather than use the min_rage data of LaserScan. Because, using this new parameter "start_clearing_range", we can work with all data sources (not only LaserScan).
I agree that your implementation is more generic than of
But I would propose a different nomeclature, to keep some consistency with the other parameters, for example, naming it "min_raytrace_range" which defaults to 0.
Also there could be another parameter "min_obstacle_range" that would do the other half of
, controlling from what distance the obstacles should be marked.

with this "min_obstacle_range".

pr_quotes: To be sure that I well understood what "min_obstacle_range" must do. If we have an hit (a point sensed) at a range of 2 meters and that min_obstacle_range is 1.5m, this point must be discarded (no clearing, and no point set). Isn't it ?
pr_details_more: Let us define D as the distance from the sensor origin to the measured point (x,y) seen by our sensor.
Let us define R as a ray/line from the sensor origin to the measured point (x,y). Note: the ray does not include the actual voxel in which the measured point falls.
min_obstacle_range - if D < min_obstacle_range, we will not mark x,y as an obstacle
max_obstacle_range (currently just obstacle_range) - if D > max_obstacle_range, we will not mark x,y as an obstacle.
min_raytrace_range - if D > min_raytrace_range, then we will start clearing along ray R from a distance min_raytrace_range from the sensor origin.
max_raytrace_range (currently just raytrace_range) - if D > max_raytrace_range, then we will stop clearing along ray R at a distance max_raytrace_range from the origin.

pr_contents: Previously the default_tolerance parameter was not used leading to
failure when the desired goal was inside an obstacle.
In case the goal is inside an obstacle the global_planner now tries to
find a cell with pot_field_max_cost as its maximum value as close as
possible around the desired goal pose. This is achieved by calculating a
potential field in the area of the desired goal pose.
This area is defined by the default_tolerance parameter.

I always forget the exact rules...does this count as ABI breaking?
Added some index checking to prevent segfaults
This change is

While I definitely see the value in this, and have been burned by it before, I'm concerned about the computational costs. Have you done side by side comparisons to see how it would affect costmap update loop times?
Also, I feel as though ignoring OOB
s is not the right move, and it should throw an exception, if anything.

We were seg faulting before we added the guards.  To me, not having the robot crash far outstrips any minimal computational cost associated with this.  As a base library that many people use, this should really be the priority.  If there is a more efficient way of doing the check, we can modify to that instead.  We considered changing the type to a std::vector instead, but the delta would be very large.
Sure, I can add a throw for the sets.
I'm also thinking getCost and setCost should not include checks -- and am also concerned about runtime implications -- here's why:
If you look at the existing codebase, pretty much everywhere we call setCost() or getCost() we call worldToMap() first -- so we'd be double checking everything in "normal" operation.

You should probably be using one of the worldToMap functions that includes a check to get your indices before calling getCost/setCost (I am presuming here that you are using costmap_2d in a custom setting, if that's not the case, then we should track down where the proper worldToMap call is missing in this codebase).

There are three different worldToMap functions -- one that just does the calculation, one that does it with bounds checking, and one that does it with checking and constraining the returned values automatically to the range of the cost map. This allows users to decide what level of checking they want to incur cost for.

I would suggest that the docs for getCost() and setCost() should be updated to note this design aspect. And yes, it is a somewhat poorly designed API (in that it is very easy to misuse, as you've found) -- however as you said, fixing the API would be a pretty big delta this late in the game. I'd definitely suggest that we should impress such an update on the navigation2 work (which doesn't end up effecting a large deployed base with such a change right now, and might still have that same API).
+1 to fixing this in navigation2

We are indeed using Costmap in a custom context.  We're doing something similar to setConvexPolygonCost except we are doing the "get" version (with very similar logic).  We call one of the mapToWorld functions to convert the footprint into costmap space and then call convexFillCells to get all the cells in order to calculate the total cost of the footprint.  It's likely the segfault is occuring during some odd corner case where convexFillCells is returning a cell that's out of the costmap indices.  We could put the check outside the getCost function, but it seems to me that a public api should guard itself against segfaults and there shouldn't be a need to translate between world and map frames in order to do that.  We could, of course, do the check outside of the getCost function.  I would however recommend that index checks inside of setConvexPolygonCost remain.
If there is interest, I could PR in our getConvexPolygonCost function as well, modifying to do the check internally instead of in getCost.

pr_code:
~<name>/<source_name>/expected_update_rate (double, default: 0.0)

    How often to expect a reading from a sensor in seconds. A value of 0.0 will allow infinite time between 
readings. This parameter is used as a failsafe to keep the navigation stack from commanding the robot 
when a sensor has failed. It should be set to a value that is slightly more permissive than the actual rate of 
the sensor. For example, if we expect a scan from a laser every 0.05 seconds we might set this parameter 
to be 0.1 seconds to give a generous buffer and account for some amount of system latency.

pr_title: [melodic] On global_planner, add skip_poses param to optionally skip a number of intermediate poses
pr_contents: The idea is to make the resulting paths less dense (and so lighter and faster to process)
If you are looking for less dense plans, is there a reason you dont prune them for your next use in an intermediate step or use a coarser costmap representation for planning?
If you are looking for less dense plans, is there a reason you dont prune them for your next use in an intermediate step or use a coarser costmap representation for planning?

Prune the path before using is a very reasonable option, for sure. But sounds like a waste of time to compose a very dense path to then remove most of the poses. As for using a coarser costmap, the risk is to close narrow passages. And in any case, halving the resolution (in our cases, 0.05 instead of 0.025) still creates unnecessary dense paths.
All that said, I agree this skip poses trick sounds like a bit "artificial", so if not interesting for more people, I will drop and do a post-processing, as you suggest.
pr_quotes: If you are looking for less dense plans, is there a reason you dont prune them for your next use in an intermediate step or use a coarser costmap representation for planning?

pr_title: [melodic] Add 'do_not_alter_costmap' parameter that forces planner to not change costmap
pr_contents: More general version of PR
, with the requested change of making the change not applicable by default. Instead of just removing the call to
, I offer now the option of not altering the costmap at all by copying its underlying char array and working only on it.

Another good thing of this approach is that we can choose (TODO in another PR) to lock the costmap only while copying it, so we allow updates during planning. This is useless on current move_base, but on

it's optional to lock the costmaps, delegating on the plugins to do so. This is a good thing for slow planners like sbpl that only invest a minimal time to copy the costmap at the beginning and then take very long while planning over his copy; on current move_base, all this time the costmap is frozen without any benefit.
