Target tab widget: is used to set target parameters, load target plugins, select Image and CameraInfo topics and publish target pose detection results.
Context tab widget: is used to choose the sensor mount type (eye-in-hand or eye-to-hand), set the initial guess pose of a camera.
Control tab widget: is used to load handeye solver plugin, config planning group name of move_group, make manual calibration and auto calibration, save camera-robot pose, save and load joint states.

Is the "Marker Size" in the Target tab referring to the size of one marker or the marker board? If it is possible to add a hover tooltip, this would be great to disambiguate (new users have much simpler questions than this).
Our FOV is not displayed. Do we need to add anything to the scene? We tried adding the target_calibration/camera/raw topic as a display to Rviz, but moving its window around caused Rviz to crash.
The marker parameters need to be set up for the detection to work. It would be very convenient to be able to save and load the parameters.

One could save the parameters by saving the Rviz config file, but when reopening Rviz, the list of Planning Groups is empty. This can be fixed by restarting the plugin, but this resets it fully, discarding the marker parameters and other settings. Can the list of planning groups be reloaded upon clicking on it, maybe?

Changing the image topic sometimes crashes Rviz. We could reproduce it a few times by saving the Rviz config with the plugin open and the image topics set, then reopening Rviz, closing the plugin, opening the plugin and setting the image topic. The error message refers to a mutex lock. I don't know if it is related to this code or an issue with Rviz.

pr_contents: I was approached by
who asked for an interface to compute forward kinematics in our Python interfaces.
After looking through some API, I found we never export any methods to python that can reason about an arbitrary robot state - Maybe I missed something?
To allow for this, I added a flag to our
to disable monitoring of the current state.
With the change, one can use
to compute arbitrary forward kinematics.
Please review briefly whether you agree with the approach or can come up with better alternatives.
Marked as WIP because this was barely tested.
Makes a lot of sense to me. I'll submit as comment because I didn't test either, but looks good to me.
LGTM, with the caveat that I didn't test that it runs. What about adding tests?
Makes sent to me, except please use longer variable names
Adding that test would be great, too
Please commit my suggestions?
This PR makes it possible to specify retime_trajectory parameters as arguments in Python interface of move_group.

I agree that having the option to specify these parameters would be very useful. However, I think it's very confusing to provide function parameters that are completely unrelated to each other (i.e. being used by different algorithms like here). I would suggest either to add algorithm-specific functions
, etc or to use an optional dictionary map for passing algorithm-specific parameters.
A dictionary map would be an elegant concept, but I find them clunky to actually use (unless a lot of parameters need to be set). Separate functions as
described would be the best in my opinion.
I would keep the parameters of
unchanged, call
etc. inside it with the default parameters, and let users use those sub-functions directly if they want to change the parameters. I don't think this is a very common use case anyway.
Thank you for comments, and sorry for late reply.
I updated as the following comment:
keep the parameters of retime_trajectory unchanged, call retime_trajectory_totg, retime_trajectory_itpt etc
(Original version is copied here:
I don't know if this is the best, so please let me know if there is a better way.

Don't recommend. BPMPD is the core optimizer for TrajOpt, it won't work without it. I think SWRI has been trying to use other optimizers, but I don't know how efficient they are.
The original TrajOpt impl is BSD-2 and included this
, so I think including the README should be fine.
a couple of other points to the discussion:

is indeed the free solver that at the moment works best with the nonlinear optimization routine implemented as in the paper. Still, it's an old, unmaintained solver, with known bugs and a flaky interface implementation. I personally implemented the
and
backends for

, admittedly with mixed results in certain cases. At SWRI they will move towards a more robust implementation of the overall optimization scheme, but for now I would, if anything, put a little bit of extra effort and try
instead of
(both interior point methods) as the standard free solver (
works nicely, by the way).
I agree with
that BPMPD is problematic as the default solver, mostly because of license issues (or rather, the lack of any license).
seems like a reasonable default choice:
I don't know how similar the BPMPD and Ipopt API's are, though.

pr_title: Configurable time parametrization method default cartesian path planner in moveit
pr_contents: This PR modifies the default cartesian path planning functionality of the moveit, allowing the user to specify the time parametrization method which is hard coded otherwise. The need for this functionality is reported in the   #
. In the issue referred, there was two possible approaches suggested to solve it. This PR deals with the second approach. And this method requires changes in the moveit_msgs package as well.
Thanks for helping in improving MoveIt
The code is failing because of it's dependency with moveit_msgs where I have added one more parameter in the service msg.
Could you review this pull request?

I added some comments in a review, but I have a higher level question. We already have a concept of a "PlanningPipeline" for doing multiple steps where we have a planner, and then have a smoother, etc. It seems like we should move in that direction for cartesian path planning as well, instead of adding ad-hoc variables for things like time parameterization.
what do you think?
Yes, I certainly agree we want to move towards unifying Cartesian planners as full fledged motion planners in moveit.
Is there a discussion anywhere on a consensus about that or how to go about it? I don't think we should cut the interpolation-based method out completely, since it is deterministic and lightweight.
Is there a discussion anywhere on a consensus about that or how to go about it? I don't think we should cut the interpolation-based method out completely, since it is deterministic and lightweight.
I don't believe the plan is to completely remove
, but to refactor it into a regular planner plugin.
It would then be possible to use the regular planning request adapter infrastructure to add things like time-parameterisation, instead of having to change
every time with ad-hoc and local hacks.
With the ability to load multiple plugins, you could then use
in combination with other planners.
pr_quotes: Is there a discussion anywhere on a consensus about that or how to go about it? I don't think we should cut the interpolation-based method out completely, since it is deterministic and lightweight.

pr_contents: Adds a feature to

to allow you to "disable" specific directions when jogging. This is particularly useful for delicate (e.g. contact) tasks, so the user can remove unwanted small commands in directions they want to be stationary in. Examples: in an insertion task you can restrict motion to the EE forward/backward direction, you can only allow pure translation/rotation, or you can keep the EE in a specific plane.
The active directions can be changed live with a service call (
). The input is a 6-long boolean array [translation-x, translation-y, translation-z, rotation-x, rotation-y, rotation-z] where passing a
sets the commanded velocity in that direction to 0, regardless of the user input. Note that the directions are defined in the commanded velocity frame
Thanks for helping in improving MoveIt
Cool, I've been wanting this feature for awhile.

Another related feature would be to allow the arm to drift in specified dimensions. Useful for passing through a singularity if you don't care about, say, wrist rotation. But we can add that later, and your PR will make it easier, I think.

pr_title: WIP: Moving objects with multiple shapes and subframes in Rviz
pr_contents: I noticed that objects with multiple shapes cannot be moved from the Rviz plugin interface, and that subframes are also not moved when moving objects through it. I was playing around with some solutions and would like to hear opinions about this one. Instead of moving only the shape of the object via
, the plugin calls a new function
that applies the same relative transformation to all of the shapes and subframes.

I am not a particularly big fan of the fact that the relative poses of the shapes and subframes will accumulate rounding errors with this approach, but without a full scene graph/transformation tree, this might be a reasonable workaround.
I also noticed that the
operation for
s is not very useful as is, since the positions of all the components have to be updated manually. That sort of defeats the purpose, in my opinion. I was thinking of a
or
command, in the absence of a scene graph. This discussion might be suited for a different issue.

This code also currently has a bug: the position of the object changes after a few moves, as if errors accumulated, but I don't see how the "main" object could, since the target position is always set relative to its frame of reference.
I use
to test.

pr_title: Implement the new move base flex interface for the global planner
pr_contents: Added a second inheritance to GlobalPlanner from the mbf_costmap_core::CostmapPlanner interface to be able to use move_base_flex while backwards compatible to move_base.
So, this really isn't going to work -- we can't depend on things from the MBF repo, since the MBF repo has packages that depend on at least costmap_2d, base_local_planner, and nav_core.
Aaa circular dependencies. :/
How could we handle that?
I think build just fails because mbf_msgs dependency is missing; same for the local planner.
I don't see any circular dependency; true mbf_costmap_core depends on costmap_2d, but also does nav_core
I believe what
means is that the ROS release infrastructure works on a per repository basis.
So circular dependencies should not only be avoided at the package level but also at the repository level. And this PR will introduce a repository level circular dependency between
and
that will prevent them from being released
There are some things to change. And some things also missing. mbf_msgs dependency, and cost is not computed or set and message is not set. The rest looks fine to me.
Yes, what
mentioned is the problem -- since we certainly want to release debians.
I think the proper way to get this out would be to include a minimal set of headers in nav_core (Ala this PR:
). Since we haven't sync'd the first round of debians yet -- it is definitely still early enough to get this into Melodic.

Or split the core stuff out of move_base_flex into a new repo (but before I would support navigation depending on said code, I'd suggest that move_base_flex_core be part of ors-planning, so that if in the future you guys decide to stop maintaining it, we can still release it and the navigation stack).
I would propose to not change navigation and handle the extended plugins at runtime in mbf.

That's what we currently do; when dealing with "old-stile" API (nav_core) plugins, MBF wraps them so they can be used indistinctly from "new-stile" API (mbf_core) plugins. Problem is that we miss the richer interface, as nav_core plugins don't provide error code or message, just success/failure, nor can be canceled (plus other new fancy stuff).
So as I see, there are several possibilities (all for melodic and later, kinetic will just remain as it is):
pr_details_more: add mbf_core and mbf_msgs to ROS navigation repo, and upgrade the plugins to the new interface (backward compatible!). Main problem is the increased complexity (possibly confusing for newcomers) of ROS navigation stack
move the plugins to a separated repo, so the can freely depend on both ROS nav (core, msgs, costmaps...) and MBF (mbf_core, mbf_msgs). Probably too much work for the maintainers.
duplicate the plugins and re-release with a mbf_ prefix. Duplicate ==
let things as they are and make a common interface (both C++ plugin and ROS API) for ROS 2.0 navigation.

pr_contents: This adds a convenience method
that warps an (end-effector) link to a given pose and subsequently checks for collisions of all warped links with the rest of the world + robot.
This method is useful for grasp planning, to check whether an end-effector can be safely placed somewhere without the need to do IK beforehand.
As a preparation of this,
lifts the definition of
from to the public API. Usually this set is initialized from the planning group, but I want to use an arbitrary set.
Finally,
does some cleanup, removing all
namespace prefixes by putting everything into a namespace.
Obviously

requires many more changes throughout the code base. Hence, I want to get some feedback first, whether you think this generalization to allow for collision checking of arbitrary link groups (in contrast to only pre-defined JMGs) is desired or not.
CI failed

to CollisionRequest/DistanceRequest?

and
could be easily specified.

My thought was that the requests could have public
members for the names of joint group and link models. The
has access to the robot model and could call
or instantiate
itself, maybe via a function
. This way we don't have to change any existing code and could also verify if new requests with selected components are valid (links are part of the robot model).
I still don't get your point. My proposal was to augment the public request with the list of robot links to be considered for collision. Up to now, you can only provide the
and from that, the link list is generated in private code. So I guess, we agree that it would be useful to specify links directly and to have a convenience function (
) to enable all links in a group.
Do you suggest to use link
instead of link
in the public interface to avoid passing invalid link pointers?
Do you suggest to use link names instead of link pointers in the public interface to avoid passing invalid link pointers?
Yes exactly this. On top of that we could keep the
and make it optional which one should be specified. It's just a suggestion to keep support for the existing interface. Setting the actual link pointers could then be done in private code.

Using link names vs. link pointers is much more costly: To get the the actual link pointers, one needs to lookup the links in a map. Keeping the existing interface, i.e. the group_name, and adding the list of link names creates an ambiguity: If both of them are filled, which one should be considered?
That's why I decided to remove the group_name and enforce users to call
Fair enough. One could filter for both parameters, i.e. if
and
is set then only the links in the corresponding group are considered. But this is definitely not necessary. I think making
public is really useful so I will approve once the conflicts and remaining changes are resolved.

whether you think this generalization to allow for collision checking of arbitrary link groups (in contrast to only pre-defined JMGs) is desired or not.

pr_contents: This PR is work done by Raghavender as a part of 2018 Google summer of code. As a part of this PR, a STOMP Smoothing adapter has been implemented. This enables the user to use STOMP as an additional post processing motion planning algorithm in a pipeline with another motion planner like CHOMP, OMPL, etc. This then produces smooth motion plans.
For tutorials on how to use this motion planning request adapter, refer to PR for a tutorial on Planning Request Adapters
. This PR also needs this PR in industrial_moveit package to be merged
in order for the STOMP smoothing adapter to function properly.
It should be noted this PR overrides an older PR
, after this PR gets merged PR
can be closed and ignored.
Please revert the last merge-commit and rebase your branch onto the kinetic-devel to resolve conflicts.
Having merge-commits within a PR-branch like this, makes it impossible to squash, or cherry-pick it to another branch later on.
what's the current state of this PR? It would be great to get this feature merged. I just think since we have the separate STOMP repo now the smoothing adapter should be added to
instead of here.
what do you think?
pr_details_more: addition of STOMP smoothing adapter into existing MoveIt Planning Request Adapters
merging of the STOMP moveit package from industrial moveit into moveit, this PR overrides this PR

use via the enhanced pos_vel_acc_eff state used by QuinticSplineSegment.

pr_contents: This is a new type of controller that accepts trajectory goals or real-time jogging commands. It can switch between the two smoothly. It was motivated by the annoyance of unloading and loading a new controller when I wanted to switch types. I would also like to inherit from this controller, later on, to make a compliant controller that can accept trajectories or velocity commands. This seems like the first step towards that goal.

It inherits from JointTrajectoryController and executes trajectories pretty much the same way. There is a bit of code added, on top of that, to accept real-time commands and forward them, like a JointGroupVelocityController. The real-time commands always interrupt trajectory execution if there is an active trajectory.
Here's a
of testing on a hardware UR3. It shows a couple trajectory/jog/trajectory/jog cycles.
Thanks for your contribution!
I am not sure if we can merge this as-is, because the behavior is not well-defined in case the velocity command gets processed while an action is active.
In addition it is not really generic, because it only works for the velocity interface.
IMHO this behavior should be implemented by switching the controllers instead, example:
It was motivated by the annoyance of unloading and loading a new controller when I wanted to switch types.
You only need to load each controller once. Afterwards you can switch between them easily.
Thank you,
. I took care of the minor comments. I think that leaves just a few more things to discuss:
The velocity is not well-defined when trajectory execution is interrupted.
The most recent commit adds a setHoldPosition() and a stopping() to make sure the robot halts (briefly, in a controlled way) when a trajectory is interrupted by a real-time command. Here's a
of how that looks at full speed. The trajectory is upward, the initial jogging is downward.
The controller is not generic.
I changed the namespace so it's under /
/TrajOrJogController, i.e. just another generic velocity controller. There's no reason why a position version wouldn't work, too, but it will take some work to blend the commands.
It makes more sense to manage controller switching with a separate, multiplexer-like node.

In my opinion that's not true, although I'm glad to have the sample code you pointed me to. That's more complexity and an extra 300+ lines of code. Ideally, you would have only one controller running and it could accept any command type, no switching needed. This moves toward the ideal solution.
Thanks for your updates, I will review them later.
Just two comments for now:
Ideally, you would have only one controller running and it could accept any command type, no switching needed. This moves toward the ideal solution.
The switching(=controller managing) is the whole point of
(and its predecessor
Most of the code is dedicated to realtime-safe switching.
although I'm glad to have the sample code you pointed me to
That's no sample code. It's a released, ready-for-use node, which enables switching between trajectory, velocity or position control with a silence filter. I think 300 lines of code are quite fair ;)
In case of Care-O-bot 4, the hardware even switches to different drive modes which have been tuned independently.

OK, thanks for the comments, although I don't completely agree. I still think the management of controller switching with a separate multiplexer node introduces extra latency and complexity. Might as well put both velocity controller types together since it takes very little effort to do so and the pause during switching will be minimized. Also, why did the authors define so many functions as virtual if they did not intend for these basic controllers to be expanded?

Let me ask a question... I need to implement a compliance controller. It will probably be a node that publishes a vector of joint speeds. These compliance joint speeds should sum with the vector of joint speeds to a JointTrajectoryController or a JointGroupVelocityController. What is your vision of how something like that should be implemented? I am interested in your opinion so I have a shot at getting it merged. Let me know if I need to explain what compliance is.
Some options I can think of:

Inherit from JointTrajectoryController and modify it to accept compliance commands. Also inherit from ForwardCommandController and modify it to accept compliance commands. This will result in two new controller types which would need to be switched by the multiplexer.
Combine JointTrajectoryController and ForwardCommandController. Inherit from that combined controller and modify it to accept compliance commands. This will result in one new controller type.
Thanks! I'm interested in what
has to say, too.
The management of controller switching with a separate multiplexer node introduces extra latency and complexity
could you better motivate why you think that? I'm not sure what I think about this debate between modular controllers vs hybrid controllers that have multiple controllers within them.
Let's look at it this way. Who do you think does the best motion control in the world? Boston Dynamics, I would say.
I don't think Boston Dynamics is pausing to load and unload controllers.
That's a bit of an argument by authority.

Ideally, you would have only one controller running and it could accept any command type, no switching needed. This moves toward the ideal solution.
although I'm glad to have the sample code you pointed me to

pr_title: update joint_trjectory controller with mimic joint support
pr_contents: I have tested your
and it works fine for the small example, but when I tried to apply that plugins to a more complex model, for example, humanoid hand model, it did not work well. I thank this because when we calculate
where the mimic joint plugin uses
as current
of the joint in gazebo simulation, but I think we have to use current
in the controller, because the current position in gazebo simulation oscillates and that makes mimic joint unstable.
Here is my workaround for supporting mimic joint in joint trajectory controller and it works well on your tutorial code. How do you think?
see
for example
we added
tag for the list of the mimic joint, and you have to add gains section. Mimic joint params (muliplier/offset) is taken from urdf model
I think your analysis is spot on. I have also observed this instability with even slightly more complex models in Gazebo, such as the
. The instability is even bigger when there are external forces, such as trying to grasp an object.
Most of the mimic joints in that model could be replaced by properly

, but there needs stil to be one mimic joint (to ensure that the right and left fingers move in sync). I haven't tested this PR, but it sounds like it could enable us to get rid of the mimic joint plugin entirely.
IMHO mimic joints should not be controlled actively.
Instead, mimic joints should be handled in RobotHW,  e.g. with transmission support.
This has the advantage that it would work for all controllers.
pr_code:
gripper_controller:
  type: position_controllers/JointTrajectoryController
  joints:
    - right_finger_joint
  mimic_joints:
    - left_finger_joint
  gains:
    right_finger_joint: {p: 20.0, i: 0.1, d: 0.2}
    left_finger_joint: {p: 20.0, i: 0.1, d: 0.2}

pr_title: Add service for checking activity of controller
pr_contents: I came up with this solution for the problem that I need to know if the robot is currently
running a trajectory.
I know there is also the query state option but "running" just means that the controller is loaded by the controller_manager and has active resources.
Is there a better way? Any suggestions?
sorry for the late reaction on this one.
How about defining a new service in
where querying the state would return a

message within? I wouldn't be opposed to extending that message if there's a good proposal or alternatively you could add the additional required fields to the proposed new service message. If something like this is added to the controller then I think we should aim to make it as informative as possible.
What would be your suggestion for states? Something like running, idle, inactive, error?
I think it'd be good if we could adopt the ROS2 lifecycle node states (or at least a subset of them)

pr_title: Dynamics controllers for Computed Torque Control / Gravity Compensation
pr_contents: Hello! During the last year I worked on some Computed Torque Controllers and I finally thought that this might be a nice addition to ROS control. In this PR, I added a new package,
whose aim is to take into account the inverse dynamics model.

Two controllers are added: one works on serial chains, while the other on whole trees. KDL is used to evaluate the efforts via the Recursive Newton-Euler algorithm. What I think is really interesting is that these controllers work only at a "high-level". In practice, they allow to instanciate a "sub-controller" (operating on an EffortJointInterface) to obtain an acceleration command - technically speaking, the produced command should be an effort, but is interpreted in a different way inside the  package.
One important remark: to compute the dynamics of kinematic trees it is necessary to use the latest version of KDL.
Let me know what you think about it and what should be improved!
First of all, we need to either get someone to update the ROS Melodic upstream KDL (tricky) or we ship a custom KDL internally with this package (not ideal).
How did you deploy this to robots locally?
In my case I have a local copy of KDL - I wrote the solver for trees so it was convenient for me to have it locally.

As far as I can tell, the only "extra" files not already in Melodic's KDL are those of the tree solver (it's just one header + the associated cpp). So as a quick and easy solution I could simply copy these files locally until the upstream is updated.
So as a quick and easy solution I could simply copy these files locally until the upstream is updated.
If this approach is chosen, I would recommend to either only include them in the compilation units that need them (ie: only include in the
) or appropriately namespace them, to avoid polluting the include path of dependants.
I manually added the sources for the Tree solver: they are all inside the
directory, so that they cannot be included in another package by mistake. In principle, once the solver becomes available, it will be necessary to simply delete the files and edit
to have everything working.
I left a few quick points from my phone, excuse my brevity.
Thanks for all the feedback, I will try to address these points in few more commits!
In the last two commits I added support for multiple sub-controllers (so that it is not strictly necessary to use a
-like controller) and also made sure that efforts are saturated according to URDF's limits.
I was considering to handle safety limits, however as far as I understand they should be enforced at the very end of the control flow directly by the
, isn't it?

To me

pr_contents: This is an update to the compliant controller first introduced in:
and
. The second of which was a messy PR and I decided to close it and open this new, clean one instead.
This new PR includes most of the code fixes requested in
, as well as new features:
Videos of the compliance controllers can be seen in the first 2 PR's. A combined video of all of the features, including the ones added for this PR,
One of the requested changes in
was adding tests, and this is still in progress, hopefully coming soon.

This may not be the correct spot to post this question, but I'm curious if this can be used to apply a constant force, rather than to avoid a force? I imagine adjusting what is considered zero would have this effect?

This may not be the correct spot to post this question, but I'm curious if this can be used to apply a constant force, rather than to avoid a force? I imagine adjusting what is considered zero would have this effect?
The equation for finding a velocity in the output frame is v = F / k - F_dot / b where F and F_dot are the force/torque and its derivative, and k and b are the user-specified stiffness and damping.

I believe this could be adjusted to apply a force rather easily. Hackily, if you increase the deadzone, you will be able to 'drive' the manipulator into applying the desired force (which would be the deadzone value).

Less hacky, the equation above could be modified. Changing the F term to be (desired force - sensed force). Thus it would behave the same with desired force = 0, but also would move the robot into applying the desired force

Thank you very much for your response, it seems like a straightforward modification after sifting through some of the code. I however, ran into some other problems in getting the controller to work with the new
(the velocity_interface branch), which I'll bring up here.

The first problem I have is that when planning some simple moves through MoveIt, it sometimes takes a few presses of the Execute button to get the robot to actually move. Further, the robot does not seem to execute any trajectory not planned through the typical "Plan" and "Execute" buttons in MoveIt. For example, I had a program written previously which simply played back a recorded motion, by copying the
topic into a trajectory... this no longer functions, and might be related to the following quirk.
I have very little experience with ROS control, but I did manage to set up ROS_Control on an ABB robot, and found that the topics published by the controller,

and the corresponding actual positions were published to constantly. However, with this controller, the topic (whose name is different) is only published to briefly when a command is issued, then quickly stops publishing anything. This results in the robot almost always being quite far (perhaps ~.1 radians in joint space) away from the desired position at the end of motions... or at least might be contributing. I'm not entirely sure.

If I have some fundamental misunderstanding of the operation of this controller, or velocity only controllers in general, please let me know... as I'm not exactly sure where to start to get better performance out of this, nor how to get more of moveit's functionality working (which is paramount, for me anyway).

Lastly, when moving the robot around by hand with compliance enabled, I found that the movement is a little bit jiggly. The end effector seems to bob up and down very noticeably (on the order of a millimeter). I'm not sure where to look to improve this behavior, but I was drawn to the

node, which at first glance, seems not to be realtime safe, and therefore may not be quite as performant as the UR driver itself...? I almost figured this might be a matter of filtering, as the command velocities do seem to oscillate a bit. Any insight into whether this behavior was noticed by you or anyone else, as well as potential places to look to improve it, would be hugely appreciated.
Thank you very much for your work on this, and everyone else who contributed. It is pretty sublime, and does almost exactly what I need.
Thanks for the extensive feedback. I will look into these problems further over the next few days. For now:

pr_code:
compliance_library:
  stiffness: [8000, 1000, 1000, 5, 40, 60] # First three element are Newtons/(m/s), last 3 are N*m/(rad/s). Should be positive.
  damping: [50000, 10000, 10000, 300, 600, 600] # First three element are Newtons/m, last 3 are N*m/rad. Should be positive.
  low_pass_filter_param: 3 # Larger > more smoothing on compliance calcs, but more lag
  deadband: [1.5, 2.5, 2.5, 0.3, 2, 2] # No reaction until force exceeds X [N, N, N, Nm, Nm, Nm]
  end_condition_wrench: [80, 80, 80, 60, 60, 60] # Safety feature. Halt if force exceeds [N, N, N, Nm, Nm, Nm]
  highest_allowable_force: 88 # Safety feature. Halt if force magnitude exceeds this across all dimensions [N]
  highest_allowable_torque: 50 # Safety feature. Halt if torque magnitude exceeds this across all dimensions [Nm]
  default_compliant_dimensions: [1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0]

pr_title: Add four wheels swerve drive to ROS controllers
pr_contents: Independent steering and control of wheels is a

. Among other advantages, it provides the user the control of three DOFs (linear speed in X and Y and angular speed in Z) whereas classical steering generally involves two DOFs only. In comparison with differential drive, the orientation of each wheel is controlled at all times to avoid slipping. Also, it can easily generalize to different robot layouts using 3+ wheels.
There is visibly a
implemented with the ros_control framework in ROS community.
This pull request contains such an implementation (for a four-wheeled robot only), developed in our startup,
. It's directly adapted from the
, and forward and backward models have been inspired from
. The package comes with a default test robot called
and a launch file (both in the test folder). A series of gtest are also included to assess odometry, X, Y linear speeds and Z angular speed. It passes
and
. Could you maybe add it to the repository?
Best,
Gabriel
I've left a couple of general review point for you out of a shallow review.
Could you please post a bit of reasoning as to why this can't be done as an extension of the
? Reason:
also has a skid-steer mode, saves a lot of duplicated code.
Hi Bence,
Thank you for the review and the relevant comments. I'm modifying the pull request accordingly. To answer to your other comment on my motivation to provide yet another controller:
The reason is that the

hypothesizes that the left and right steering mechanisms are physically linked together in the front and in the back, forming, therefore, a back and a front train which turn with the same angle. This constraint leads to simplifications in the controller equations but also restrict the problem to a specific set of robot mechanisms.
The
also has a skid-steer mode but, in this case, the wheels are not steered independently around the z-axis.

In this swerve_controller, we consider a much more generalistic case, where all four wheels have an independent steering mechanism to turn around the z-axis. This can lead to a larger range of available movements (linear x and y speeds as well as z angular speed). The only constraints that remain in the code concern are geometrical considerations to position all the wheels around the same rotation center (see image below)
Hi!
Is there any news regarding this pull request?
Best,
Gabriel

pr_contents: As found out by others as well, there is a small issue in some controllers when a revolute joints has "large" limits, see eg
The problem is that some position controllers call the function
, which assumes that the total allowed range of rotation is lower than
. Therefore, if one has as limits such as
will assume that the valid range has size
instead of
. To allow dealing with larger rotations, the PR
introduced the function
I updated three controllers to use such function in case
is greater than or equal to
. I tested it and the oscillations that could be experienced before now disappear.
